ygData.subject: Re: [cantera] Activity Coefficient
ygData.msgSnippet: Thanks David, I had a look at the direction you told and yes the is the DebyeHuckell implementation of the activity coefficient.  And as rightly documented it

Content-Type: text/plain; charset=iso-8859-1
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 8bit

Thanks David,
   
  I had a look at the direction you told and yes the is the DebyeHuckell implementation of the activity coefficient.  And as rightly documented it is for dilute solution.  I am interested in concentrated solution but the important point is the infrastrucutre is there and we can develop things from that.  I'll see if I have the time to develop the Pitzer implementation of this activity coefficients.  In the mean time how can I download the source codes for the C++ and matlab version of CANTERA without going to source forge or something like that?  Thanks for the service you have done to the scientific community.  
   
  sincerely,
   
   
  ric

David Goodwin <dgoodwin@...> wrote:
          Yes, it can do this. Harry Moffat has taken the lead in implementing 
these capabilities. First take a look at the reference documentation 
on the web site, and then look at the source files in directory 
Cantera/src/thermo.

On Apr 24, 2007, at 2:06 AM, ric_lpz wrote:

> Hello Everybody!
>
> I am new to this group. I would like to know if CANTERA can calculate
> activity coefficient in electrolyte solution in equilibrium. If yes
> what method does it use, eg, Meisnner, Pitzer, Bromley, etc? Can you
> please point me in the proper direction were the find the necessary
> files if it is available.
>
> Thanks,
>
> ric
>
>
>
>
> Yahoo! Groups Links
>
>
>



         

       
---------------------------------
